climbs.name: Seal Team Six
climbs.fa: Tyler Phillips, Brendan Brinkley 2011   P2: Tyler Phillips, Pat and Kristen Bardsley 2016

content.description:
P1: This is the rightmost of the three bolted lines above the huge boulder. Look for black-painted bolts. 5-ish bolts lead up, trending right, to anchor bolts with rap rings. 10c/d. If doing the second pitch don't go to the anchors, step out left at the 4th bolt and go straight up to the shelf passing two bolts to an amazing ledge. 10b

P2: From the best belay ledge at Lisa Falls head up a really fun and steep crack to steep juggy moves to an anchor. Take a light rack of cams and stoppers. 10b
content.protection:
P1: Bolts

P2: Bolts and gear

climbs.name: The Patriot Act
climbs.fa: Tyler Phillips, Luke Douglas, Jeremy Polk 2014

content.description:
The first line above the lower falls. This route is short, but good. Four bolts lead to a two bold anchor with chains. Head up on some angular slopey holds to clip the first 2 bolts. There's a horizontal crack just above the second bolt where you can get a good hand jam, but I couldn't clip the third bolt from here. At this point you either do a cruxy move out left onto a bit of slab to clip the 3rd bolt or go right (I think this is the intended line) on more slopers to an undercling. I found these moves pumpy and was grateful for the jug of an undercling because this brings you to the crux of pulling up left to get above the 3rd bolt. 4th bolt is chest level at this point and clipping stance is decent. A couple more moves gets you into a low angle chimney to the anchors.

The route seemed short, but I was there when snow covered the stream and probably cit off the first 5-10 feet of the climb.

Looks like it would be fairly easy to traverse right to the anchors of Land of the Free to top rope, but I found the .11a more straight forward than and just as strenuous as the .10d
content.protection: 4 draws and 2 more for the anchor. Chains at the top.

content.description: Just to the right of The Patriot Act, mildly positive angular holds and crimps get you past the first bolt to a jug. Clip the second bolt from here. I was tempted to rest at this jug, but club a couple moves more to a fixed nut where you can stem and rest with practically no hands. Another nut is above your head (.4 and .5 c4 could replace these if they disappear) head right from here across slopers and hand jams to the alcove below the anchors. A large chunk of guano is the main obstacle at this point as you gently pull up into the corner and make a move left to the anchors.
content.protection: 2 bolts, 0.4 & 0.5 c4 or medium to large nuts, #1 C4. The anchor is two hanger less bolts that go directly through the chains.

content.description: Right of the upper falls, at the base of a steep ugly looking gully, are 2 routes.  This is the right route that climbs the nicer angled face.  Be carefull of the gully on the right as it is LOOSE.  This 5.10b is not to be confused with the other 5.10b in this area.  Not steep, not pumpy, only short.  Thin edges and crystals, Not a solid handhold on the climb.  This is one fun climb.
content.protection: 3 draws for the climb and 2 more for the chains at the top.

content.description: After the slab scramble on the right of the stream, you can cross over to the left again.  Hike past a boulder and the first line of bolts (3) are this climb.  Steep climbing and funky moves are the name of the game.  Lieback up the diagonalling rows of rock to gain the top.  Love that double knob, near the top. Clips seemed to be a little strenuous, but not too hard.
content.protection: 3 draws for the route and 2 more for the chains.

content.description:
This climb starts above the huge boulder at the edge of the water.  Climb straight up for 20 ft., then follow crack systems angling right for a long ways to a set of chains at the top of the cliff.

Avoid this route at all costs.  It's a mega-choss pile.
content.protection: gear to 4".  A few large pieces helpful.

content.description: This is the middle of three bolted routes on the left wall above the huge boulder.  Angle up and right following four bolts, then straight up past two more bolts to rap hangers.
